page.title: 13WILDLIFE IN THE HIGH WEALD
page.content: Many of the estates have large areas which are rarely disturbed by man and therefore an ideal environment for all types of wildlife.{Deer}are often seen on walks and the fallow deer make sorties into gardens. Foxes, badgers, stoats and weasels, grey squirrels, and in the evening bats can be found. {Rabbits}have recently been the victims of{myxomatosis,}so are fewer in numbers in 1985 than usual. Pheasants, partridges, wild duck and some hares make pleasant hunting for foxes. All the well known varieties of {birds}such as robins, tits and thrushes abound, and woodpeckers, hawks, kestrels and owls also. Many common{butterflies}can be seen plus the Purple Emperor and White Admiral. Crested Newts are found in the ponds. There are many grass{snakes,}sometimes adders and various ants and spiders.
